variant.question: An aircraft flies from London to South France and experiences a strong wind from the left. Which of the following is correct?

options.text: The true altitude will decrease.
The true altitude remains constant.
The radio altimeter shows a climb.
The true altitude will increase.

variant.question: During the cruise at FL270, on a northerly heading from Paris to London, there is a strong crosswind from the right. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the aircraft's altitude?

options.text: The aircraft's true altitude will be increasing.
The indicated altitude from the aneroid altimeter will be decreasing.
The pressure altitude will be increasing.
The radio altimeter will show a decrease in altitude.

variant.question: Imagine an airfield during summer with sunny days and clear nights and with a runway parallel to the shoreline of a large inland lake 5 NM away from the field. A small aircraft heading for the airfield in the afternoon experiences wind shear during approach and a cross wind component which makes landing difficult. The origin of the wind shear and cross wind is most likely to be seen in

options.text: a strong sea breeze blowing more or less perpendicular to the runway.
a radiation inversion due to surface cooling during the clear night.
a strong land breeze blowing more or less perpendicular to the runway.
a subsidence inversion typical for summer anticyclones causing variations in wind speed and direction near the surface.

variant.question: During an approach to land an aircraft experiences a headwind at 4000 ft followed by an increasing crosswind component from the right in the friction layer. The wind shift:

options.text: Is typical in the southern hemisphere.
Is typical in the northern hemisphere.
Results from a cold front advection in the southern hemisphere.
Results from a warm front advection in the southern hemisphere.

variant.question: Whilst flying at FL180 on the northern hemisphere an aircraft experiences right drift. What effect, if any, will this have on the aircraft's true altitude?

options.text: It decreases.
It increases.
It remains constant.
Without knowing the pressure change this question cannot be answered.

variant.question: An aircraft is approaching under visual flight rules an airfield (northern hemisphere) whose runway is parallel to the coast. When downwind over the sea, the airfield is on the left. What wind effect should be anticipated on final approach and landing during a sunny summer afternoon?

options.text: Crosswind from the left.
Headwind.
Tailwind.
Crosswind from the right.

variant.question: An aircraft is flying from Paris to London, wind is coming from the right side. What would you expect?

options.text: True altitude is increasing.
True altitude remains constant.
A right drift.
True altitude is descreasing.

variant.question:
Refer to figure. 
 If all 4 of the aircraft in the diagram are flying close to the surface, which is experiencing the most headwind?

options.text: Aircraft C
Aircraft D
Aircraft B
Aircraft A

variant.question: After a sunny spring day and a cloudless night, you depart from an inland airport with calm winds. Soon after takeoff, the wind veers sharply and increases in speed, and your low-level wind shear warning goes on in the cockpit. What meteorological phenomena can cause this?

options.text: Nocturnal Jet.
Super geostrophic winds.
Topographic jet stream.
Inverted jet.

variant.question:
Sample Question Generated from Incomplete Feedback
After a sunny spring day and a cloudless night you depart from an inland airport with calm winds.Soon after takeoff the wind veers sharply and increases in speed and your low level windshear warning goes off in the cockpit. What meteorological phenomena can cause this?

options.text: Nocturnal Ground Inversion causing a nocturnal low-level jet
Gust front from a nearby thunderstorm
Thermal turbulence
Standing wave activity from nearby hills

variant.question:
After a warm, sunny day in spring, followed by a cold, clear night, a flight crew departing from an inland aerodrome just before sunrise report an unexpected and significant change in windspeed just after take-off, causing a cockpit wind shear warning. 
What meteorological phenomenon is the most probable reason for this?

options.text: Nocturnal low-level jet.
Low-level sting jet.
A squall line jet.
Polar night jet.

variant.question: A horizontal tailwind gust may cause an aeroplane to

options.text: descend.
climb or descend depending on gust strength.
climb.
have no effect on the flight path.

variant.question:
During an approach to land an aircraft experiences a headwind at 4000 ft followed by an increasing crosswind component from the right in the friction layer.
 The wind shift

options.text: Is typical in the southern hemisphere.
Results from a cold front advection in the southern hemisphere.
Is typical in the northern hemisphere.
Results from a warm front advection in the southern hemisphere.

variant.question: On the approach you encounter a windshear - a change in a horizontal tailwind will cause

options.text: a descent or climb depending upon the strength and type of the gust.
an increase in TAS.
a descent only.
a climb.

variant.question: What can be said if you encounter +FZRA during flight?

options.text: Icing will most probably occur.
Only light rime ice has to be expected.
There is no significant icing to expect.
Freezing rain consists of water droplets which supercool to below-freezing temperatures on impact.

variant.question: You are planning an IFR flight and there is a warm front on your route. Flying around it is not possible and the performance of the aircraft does not allow to climb over it. How should you plan your route?

options.text: Plan your route through the warm front on the shortest way possible.
Orbit at the end of it and wait for it to pass.
Fly 500 ft below MSA in IMC and fly below it.
Fly parallel, along the front line and try to pass it through a gap.

variant.question: If the windshear due to microbursts is expected to occur during take-off, the best solution is to:

options.text: Delay departure
Perform reduced take-off thrust
Select to lower climb speed
Avoid the shear area visually

variant.question: A wide body takes off on a clear night in Dhahran, Saudi Arabia. Shortly after take off the aircraft`s rate of climb drops to zero. This can be due to...

options.text: a very strong temperature inversion
low relative humidity
sand/dust in the engines
very pronounced downdrafts

variant.question: Due to a wind-shear event during an approach to land, the headwind component suddenly increases just before the flare. If the pilot does NOT take appropriate action, this could lead to..

options.text: the aircraft "ballooning" and landing beyond the touch&down aiming point, increasing the possibility of a runway excursion.
the aircraft descending and its trajectory going below the intended descent profile.
a sudden drop in indicated airspeed and associated "ballooning" during the flare, leading to a heavy landing short of the touch&down aiming point.
the development of a loss-of-energy situation, requiring a swift increase in engine power.

variant.question: Due to a wind-shear event during an approach to land, the headwind component suddently increases just before the flare. If the pilot does NOT take appropriate action, this could lead to...

options.text: the aircraft "ballooning" and landing beyond the touch-down aiming point, increasing the possibility of a runway excursion.
a sudden drop in indicated airspeed and associated "ballooning" during the flare, leading to a heavy landing short of the touch-down aiming point.
the development of a loss-of-energy situation, requiring a swift increase in engine power.
the aircraft descending and its trajectory going below the intended descent profile.

variant.question: During flight the headwind increases suddenly due to wind shear. What initial effect does that have on true airspeed?

options.text: There will be a sudden temporary increase in true air speed.
None, since wind only affects ground speed and drift.
There will be a sudden temporary decrease in true air speed.
There will only be a gradual increase in true airspeed until equilibrium is established again.

variant.question: During the approach, the tower reports a wind shear that is less than 20 kt and the pilot needs to land at its destination. What decision should the pilot take?

options.text: Delay the approach as the wind shear, even small, is a big threat for the landing at this airport.
Land on the initially intended runway as the aircraft is specifically designed to withstand such wind shears.
Land on the runway in use since it has been chosen to be the less affected by the wind shear.
Request the opposite runway as the wind shear will have fewer effects.

variant.question: Before a planned take-off, wind shear is forecast. What is the most advisable course of action?

options.text: Delay the take-off.
Reduce take-off thrust.
Select a lower climb speed.
Initially climb at a shallow angle.

variant.question: When established on the final approach path, and after passing below a cloud associated with a microburst, an aircraft can experience..

options.text: pitch changes without pilot input.
alternating yawing movements.
reduced visibility.
increasing headwind.

variant.question: During an ILS approach on RWY 33, a northwesterly wind is blowing parallel to the runway. Its speed is increasing rapidly with height while its change in direction is negligible. What has the pilot to be aware of with respect to wind shear and glide path (no autopilot engaged)?

options.text: Without the pilot's intervention, the aircraft is likely to fly below the designated glide path with increasing deviation from it.
Without the pilot's intervention, the aircraft is likely to fly above the designated glide path with increasing deviation from it.
A deviation from the glide path will not have to be considered since there is no significant wind shear to be expected.
Without the pilot's intervention, the aircraft is likely to fly above the designated glide path with decreasing deviation from it.

variant.question: During an ILS approach on RWY 33, a northwesterly wind is blowing parallel to the runway. Its speed is decreasing rapidly with height while its change in direction is negligible. What has the pilot to be aware of with respect to wind shear and glide path (no autopilot engaged)?

options.text: intensity of vertical and horizontal wind shear.
stability of the air.
intensity of the solar radiation.
height of the aircraft.

variant.question: During an ILS approach on RWY 33, a north-westerly wind is blowing parallel to the runway. Its speed is increasing rapidly with height while its change in direction is negligible. What has the pilot to be aware of with respect to wind shear and glide path (no autopilot engaged)?

options.text: Without the pilot`s intervention, the aircraft is likely to fly below the designated glide path with increasing deviation from it.
Without the pilot`s intervention, the aircraft is likely to fly above the designated glide path with increasing deviation from it.
A deviation from the glide path will not have to be considered since there is no significant wind shear to be expected.
Without the pilot`s intervention, the aircraft is likely to fly above the designated glide path with decreasing deviation from it.

variant.question: During an ILS approach on RWY 33, a north-westerly wind is blowing parallel to the runway. Its speed is decreasing rapidly with height while its change in direction is negligible. What has the pilot to be aware of with respect to wind shear and glide path (no autopilot engaged)?

options.text: Without the pilot`s intervention, the aircraft is likely to fly above the designated glide path with increasing deviation from it.
Without the pilot`s intervention, the aircraft is likely to fly below the designated glide path with increasing deviation from it.
A deviation from the glide path will not have to be considered since there is no significant wind shear to be expected.
Without the pilot`s intervention, the aircraft is likely to fly below the designated glide path with decreasing deviation from it.

variant.question: What should you do in order to avoid embedded TS?

options.text: Use the stormscope to locate the cells.
Circumnavigate the CB.
Overfly the CB.
Attempt flight beneath thunderstorm.

During an ILS approach on RWY 33, a north-westerly wind is blowing parallel to the runway

 What has the pilot to be aware of with respect to wind shear and glide path (no autopilot engaged)?
